data.title: The War at Home (1979)
data.meta_description: Documentary film about the anti-war movement in the Madison, Wisconsin area during the time of the Vietnam War. It combines archival footage and interviews with participants that explore the events of the period on the University of Wisconsin–Madison campus.
data.text:
I like watching horror films in October, and I also like to watch normal movies on Halloween (stay tuned for my Elvira review, though).

Glenn Silber talked about how he wanted to restore his 1979 documentary (which took several years) as his contribution to the resistance. While being a strong documentary about the people who protested the Vietnam war, I think the director is overconfident that young people just need to see this work and they will magically rise up against Trump. There needs to be a plan. I think citizens should protest if they are dissatisfied with the current administration. However, I've kept waiting over the past couple of years: is this the moment when people are going to…

I was part of the Kickstarter campaign to get this film restored, so I am glad I got to see this theatrically. Seeing it theatrically made me even more glad that this film got restored. Telling the story of the anti-war movement at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, this film explores how social movements grow, change and in some cases fall. In a time like the present, where there are copious reasons for activism, protest and social unrest, this is an invaluable film. Glenn Silber described the core message of this film as "the importance of the movement staying nonviolent" and said "you also see how the movement grew from just a few hundred people to a mass movement." i found this to b a really uninteresting & frustrating doc.

it talks about who the anti-war protesters are, & it shows them saying they didn't want to fight & didn't believe in war.

but it isn't interested it seems in why it might not have been the worst idea in the world to try to battle communist expansion.

there's a moment where a mother talks about her son coming home in a body bag, and she asks 'what are we dying for?'

& there's an answer to that, and this movie never gives that answer. why not? if you're going to make a doc on the topic, why not at least try to steelman the other side?
